div.p: Building a 2 colors Commander deck is always tricky. Compared to the other configurations (1 color and 3+ colors), 2 colors decks have less ways of fixing their manabase than other combinations.
That's why it's particularly important to know what your options are if you want to make the most out of your manabase.
More restrictive than Clifftop Retreat because it requires you to have an actual Mountain or a Plains in your starting hand.
More flexible than Furycalm Snarl because you can keep a hand with a fetch land in addition to Clifftop Retreat.
Doesn't really fix your mana but at least you get to choose your color.
Instant speed fixing for both of your colors if you happen to already have one of those two colors. Provides you colorless mana in the meantime.
Instant speed fixing for your deck with a 1 life drawback each time. Won't hurt you if you don't need the colored mana.
Instant speed fixing for your deck with a 1 life drawback each time. Can replace itself if you are desperate to draw a card.
No drawback in a Commander game other than not being fetchable.
Almost as good as it's older brother, Plateau.
Prefered target when cracking an Arid Mesa if you have no relevant play to follow with.
The king of dual lands: Perfect, no drawback, no tempo loss.
I only ranked Arid Mesa higher because of the amazing flexibility.
This is the perfect land for your Boros Commander deck.

It's a Mountain when you need it. It's a Plains when you need it. If your budget allows it, it can be a Plateau at instant speed. If you have nothing else to play, it can be a Sacred Foundry that enters the battlefield tapped.

You should always wait until the last minute to crack your fetch land: if you need to play Swords to Plowshares at instant speed or a Pyroblast at the end of your opponent's turn, just go fetch a Plateau, otherwise, at the end of your opponent's turn, go fetch a Sacred Foundry and let it enter the battlefield tapped.

Cracking a fetch land and shuffling your library is also what makes it so good. If for whatever reason, you're not happy with your scry, or the cards you put back on top of your library with a Scroll Rack, you can get rid of them by cracking the Arid Mesa.
Fetch lands are also good targets for recursion spells or abilities like Brought Back, Sevinne's Reclamation or Sun Titan.
You can also double your fetch land activations with cards like Rings of Brighthearth.
Building a 2 colors Commander deck is always tricky. Compared to the other configurations (1 color and 3+ colors), 2 colors decks have less ways of fixing their manabase than other combinations.
That's why it's particularly important to know what your options are if you want to make the most out of your manabase.
More restrictive than Sulfur Falls because it requires you to have an actual Island or a Mountain in your starting hand.
More flexible than Frostboil Snarl because you can keep a hand with a fetch land in addition to Sulfur Falls.
Doesn't really fix your mana but at least you get to choose your color.
Instant speed fixing for both of your colors if you happen to already have one of those two colors. Provides you colorless mana in the meantime.
Instant speed fixing for your deck with a 1 life drawback each time. Won't hurt you if you don't need the colored mana.
Instant speed fixing for your deck with a 1 life drawback each time. Can replace itself if you are desperate to draw a card.
No drawback in a Commander game other than not being fetchable.
Almost as good as it's older brother, Volcanic Island.
Prefered target when cracking a Scalding Tarn if you have no relevant play to follow with.
The king of dual lands: Perfect, no drawback, no tempo loss.
I only ranked Scalding Tarn higher because of the amazing flexibility.
This is the perfect land for your Izzet Commander deck.

It's an Island when you need it. It's a Mountain when you need it. If your budget allows it, it can be a Volcanic Island at instant speed. If you have nothing else to play, it can be a Steam Vents that enters the battlefield tapped.

You should always wait until the last minute to crack your fetch land: if you need to play Dispel at instant speed or a Pyroblast at the end of your opponent's turn, just go fetch a Volcanic Island, otherwise, at the end of your opponent's turn, go fetch a Steam Vents and let it enter the battlefield tapped.

Cracking a fetch land and shuffling your library is also what makes it so good. If for whatever reason, you're not happy with your scry, or the cards you put back on top of your library with a Scroll Rack or Brainstorm, you can get rid of them by cracking the Scalding Tarn.
You can also double your fetch land activations with cards like Rings of Brighthearth.

That's why it's particularly important to know what your options are if you want to make the most out of your manabase.
More restrictive than Hinterland Harbor because it requires you to have an actual Forest or an Island in your starting hand.
You cannot keep your hand if this is your only land, other than that, you are good to go.
Doesn't really fix your mana but at least you get to choose your color.

Almost as good as it's older brother, Tropical Island.
Prefered target when cracking an Misty Rainforest if you have no relevant play to follow with.
The king of dual lands: Perfect, no drawback, no tempo loss.
I only ranked Misty Rainforest higher because of the amazing flexibility.
This is the perfect land for your Simic Commander deck.

It's a Forest when you need it. It's an Island when you need it. If your budget allows it, it can be a Tropical Island at instant speed. If you have nothing else to play, it can be a Breeding Pool that enters the battlefield tapped.

You should always wait until the last minute to crack your fetch land: if you need to play Worldly Tutor or Dispel at instant speed, just go fetch a Tropical Island, otherwise, at the end of your opponent's turn, go fetch a Breeding Pool and let it enter the battlefield tapped.

Cracking a fetch land and shuffling your library is also what makes it so good. If for whatever reason, you're not happy with your scry, or the cards you put back on top of your library with a Scroll Rack or Brainstorm, you can get rid of them by cracking the Misty Rainforest.
Fetch lands are also good targets for recursion spells or abilities like Crucible of Worlds.
You can also double your fetch land activations with cards like Rings of Brighthearth.

Will shine more in decks relying heavily on Black. Will provide colorless mana in the meantime.

It's a Swamp when you need it. It's an Forest when you need it. If your budget allows it, it can be a Bayou at instant speed. If you have nothing else to play, it can be a Overgrown Tomb that enters the battlefield tapped.

You should always wait until the last minute to crack your fetch land: if you need to play Vampiric Tutor or Worldly Tutor at instant speed, just go fetch a Bayou, otherwise, at the end of your opponent's turn, go fetch a Overgrown Tomb and let it enter the battlefield tapped.

Cracking a fetch land and shuffling your library is also what makes it so good. If for whatever reason, you're not happy with your scry, or the cards you put back on top of your library with a Scroll Rack or Sylvan Library, you can get rid of them by cracking the Verdant Catacombs.

Hello everybody! Let me introduce myself.
My name is Ludovic Heyberger, and I've been playing Magic The Gathering since 1995.
I discovered the game with the 4th Edition and Ice Age and I've been playing until Tempest.
I started playing again 5 years later with Onslaught, Legion and Sourge, and I never stopped since then.
I discovered Commander in 2015, became immediately addicted and never looked back at other formats.
This website is my humble attempt at contributing to this wonderful format.
